title: Bahamas - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 4 February 2021, in Nassau, New Providence, nurses gathered outside the Ministry of Health to demand that the government delivers on its promise to pay extra for the hours nurses worked during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 3 February 2021, in Nassau, New Providence, nurses gathered outside the Ministry of Health to demand that the government delivers on its promise to pay extra for the hours nurses worked during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=no report]

On 1 February 2021, in Nassau, New Providence, dozens of nurses gathered outside the Ministry of Health to demand that the government delivers on its promise to pay nurses a bonus for the hours worked during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=dozens]
On 19 December 2020, in Nassau, New Providence, around 40 people protested against oil-drilling in Bahamian waters, which is bound to start soon. [size=around 40]
On 15 December 2020, in Freeport, City of Freeport, environmentalists protested against the arrival of a drilling ship in Bahamian waters. [size=no report]

On 7 October 2020, in Nassau, New Providence, scores of employees of a resort protested to demand the official termination of their contract and the payment of severance compensation. The resort has been closed for months due to coronavirus . One person in the crowd attempted to incite a riot and was quickly arrested, before dthe police dispersed the group. [size=scores]

On 18 August 2020, in Nassau, New Providence, police arrested a number of protesters who were protesting against restrictive coronavirus measures in the country and the economic hardship resulting from these measures. The arrests were made because protesters had not the required permission to protest as the country remains in lockdown. [size=no report[

On 5 August 2020, in Nassau, New Providence, approximately 60 health workers of the Princess Margaret Hospital walked off their job and protested outside for an hour before going back to work. The workers protested against the lack of personal protective equipment in the hospital to prevent the spread of coronavirus. [size=approximately 60]
On 2 August 2020, off the coast of Little Hawksbill Cay, Exuma, the coast guard of the Bahamas found and detained 44 Haitian illegal migrants.

On 13 June 2020, in Nassau, New Providence, three men in a car opened fire on a police officer. The officer and his colleagues returned fire, killing all three men. It is unclear why the men in the car opened fire on the officers. 3 fatalities.

On 2 June 2020, in Nassau, New Providence, at least 20 fishermen and merchants gathered at the Montagu shore to protest. They asked the government to allow them to go back to work. The markets have been closed since mid-March due to coronavirus. [size=at least 20]

On 20 March 2020, throughout the Bahamas a curfew was imposed to prevent spread of the coronavirus. On 27 March 2020 the borders of the Bahamas were closed to all incoming visitors including citizens.
On 03 January 2020 in Nassau, a former constable in the Royal Bahamas Police Force was shot and killed on the street, when two persons came out of a car and shot him.

On 01 January 2020 in Nassau, several people were beaten by the police with batons, one man was knocked to the ground by police and injured. This was during a parade and police were attempting to disperse people.
Labour Group (Bahamas); BHCAWU: Bahamas Hotel Catering and Allied Workers Union

On 28 November 2019 on Paradise Island, Nassau, members of the Bahamas Hotel Catering and Allied Workers Union (BHCAWU) protested outside the Atlantis resort over lengthy industrial agreement negotiations. [size=no report]

On September 04, 2029, unconfirmed reports claim that clashes took place between a group of Haitian-Bahamians and police forces in an unidentified area in Abaco Islands in the Bahamas. Helicopters of the US Coast Guards were seen landing in the area with some reports claiming that they were dispatched to the area to help victims of Hurricane Dorian. Neither injuries nor fatalities were reported.

On August 27 2019, in Nassau, New Providence, doctors and health workers as members of the Bahamas Doctors Union staged a demonstration march to Rawson Square to demand payments that were owed for several years to them by the government for holiday work days. [size=no report]
BPSU: Bahamas Public Services Union; Labour Group (Bahamas)

On August 22, 2019, in downtown Nassau, hundreds of workers from the Bahamas Public Services Union (BPSU) protested outside the Cabinet, demanding the prime minister to follow through on his promises for a pay increase. [size=hundreds]

On August 1, 2019, in Nassau, police officers entered the home of a family. They are reported to have beaten some family members and shot their guns on the property. Some family members were apprehended on immigration charges.

On May 21 2019, in Nassau, New Providence, workers of the National Insurance Board staged a demonstration by blocking the street in front of their main offices to report the company of their operations that leave workers without their benefits including maternity benefits and claim that the system of compensations and payments is inefficient because of the way the system is corrupted, and they blamed the director of the Board of it. [size=no report]
On February 6 2019, parents of the C.W. Sawyer Primary School, protested outside of the school in Nassau, Bahamas, against the poor conditions the school is in. [size=no report]
On 30 January 2019, almost a thousand taxi drivers went on strike and took the streets of Nassau, Bahamas to protest tour bus operations. [size=almost a thousand]

On 22 November 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, teachers members of the Union of Tertiary Educations staged a demonstration outside The Bahamas University against the dean of the university for delays in promotions, payments and union busting. [size=no report]
On 21 November 2018, protesters took the streets of Nassau, Bahamas, to protest the increasing electricity prices.
On 21 November 2018, professors protested in front of the University of the Bahamas, in Nassau, against a new labor agreement.
On 21 November 2018, protesters of the opposition (PLP) protested in front of the Parliament in Nassau, Bahamas, to demand the resignation of the Prime Minister.
On 20 November 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, hundreds of citizens staged a demonstration on Bay street against high unemployment rates and rising electricity bills. [size=hundreds]
On 12 November 2018, employees of the Bahamas Telecommunication Company (BTC) protested in front of the headquarters in Nassau, against the upcoming downsizing of the company.
On 31 October 2018, nurses took the streets of Nassau, Bahamas, to protest a new shift system.

On 30 October 2018, in Freeport, City of Freeport, a group of nurses of Rand Memorial Hospital staged a demonstration outside the hospital against the change of shifts implemented by the Public Hospitals authority. [size=no report]
On 29 October 2018, nurses employed at the Princess Margaret Hospital in Nassau, Bahamas, protested outside of the hospital against a new shift system.

On 19 October 2018, in Arthurs Town, Cat Island, a group of parents of students staged a demonstration outside the high school of the sector to demand the assignment of teachers to the school as they do not have enough teachers for all students. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2018, in Alice Town, Bimini, a group of students of the Louise Macdonald high school staged a demonstration outside the campus to complain about the Ministry of Education's decision of redeploying a teacher who had been fired for behaving inappropriately. [size=no report]
On 20 September 2018, physicians employed at the Princess Margaret Hospital in Nassau, Bahamas, protested outside of the hospital against the poor hospital conditions.
On 19 September 2018, junior physicians protested at the Princess Margaret Hospital in Nassau, Bahamas. They claim they are being denied certain employment benefits.

On 1 August 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, a group of nurses staged a demonstration outside Princess Margaret Hospital to complain about the Public Hospital Authorities and Health Ministry decisions, claiming that they are attempting to bust unions. [size=no report]

On 14 June 2018, demonstrators took the streets of Nassau, Bahamas, to demonstrate against a government plan to increase certain taxes. The demonstrators broke down barricades set up in front of the Parliament.

On 26 May 2018, in Freeport, City of Freeport, a group of taxicab drivers staged a demonstration outside the Ocean Reef resort, complaining about guests being illegally transported in unfranchised cars, and not using the legal taxicabs. [size=no report]
On 9 May 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, around 50 citizens staged a demonstration on Rawson square against the Minnis administration. [size=around 50]
On 11 April 2018, street vendors protested in Nassau, Bahamas, against the closing of several stalls and certain government policies.

On 22 March 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, more than 60 students, teachers and alumni of The Bahamas University staged a demonstration against the institution's decision to ban the decoration and use of mortarboard hats during graduation ceremonies. [size=more than 60]
On 15 March 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, a group of citizens staged a demonstration in Rawson square against the Minnis administration. [size=no report]

On 20 February 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, a group of National Insurance Board workers staged a demonstration outside the main offices in Baillou Hill Road, after they learned that they would not receive increments of the payments the institution owes them. [size=no report]

On 1 February 2018, in Nassau, New Providence, a group of students of The Bahamas University staged a demonstration to demand the university to make a plea to motorists to make the sector safer for pedestrians. [size=no report]

The largest admin1 is New Providence with 37 reports followed by City of Freeport with 3 reports.
